Fig. 1 The curves of NO conversion rate with temperature in the NH3-SCR reaction of fresh (a) and aged (b) Fe-T series catalysts (B Hydrothermal aging conditions:800 °C,6 h,10 %H2O; test condition:500ppmNO,500ppmNH3,5 %O2,5 %CO2, 5 %H2O and N2 as balance gas, GHSV=100000h−). Fig 1 Fig. 2 The curves of NO conversion rate with temperature in NH3-SCR reaction of fresh(a) and aged(b) Cu-T series catalysts. Fig 2 Fig. 3 XRD patterns of fresh (a) and aged (b) Cu (Fe) -T zeolite samples (Hydrothermal aging B conditions: 800 °C, 6 h, 10 % H2O). In this experiment, a highly crystalline T-type zeolite was rapidly synthesized by hydrothermal method within 24 h and its NH3-SCR catalytic performance after Cu2+or Fe3+modification was studied. The experimental results show that T-type molecular sieve is workable in industrial tail gas denitrification. The F-Fe-T series samples can maintain more than 80 % of the nitrogen oxide conversion rate in the range of 280–600 °C and the F-Cu-T catalyst could achieve more than 80 % at about 170 °C. At the same time, it was found that the zeolites modified by two metal ions had obvious differences in hydrothermal stability. The results suggested that the Fe-T catalyst can maintain excellent crystal structure and NH3-SCR catalytic activity even after hydrothermal aging at 800 °C for 6 h, but the skeleton structure of the Cu-T catalyst is completely destroyed. The main reason may be that a small amount of FeOx species with a low degree of agglomeration formed in the fresh Fe-T series catalysts, which interacted with the framework Al to form Fe-O-Al species and FeOx species were re-dispersed into isolated Fe3+species during hydrothermal aging, thus avoiding a large amount of hydrolysis of the framework Al. The framework Al of Cu-T series catalysts are hydrolysed during hydrothermal aging, which leads to the deactivation of the catalyst. In summary, T-type zeolites exhibit excellent catalytic activity after copper or iron ion exchange, but the Fe-T series catalysts have better hydrothermal stability. Introduction Nitrogen oxides are a kind of air pollutants with great harm. Excessive emissions of nitrogen oxides will not only damage people 's respiratory systems but also react with air substances, resulting in nitric acid rain and optical smog [1,2]. The commonly used method is ammonia selective reduction of nitrogen oxides (NH3-SCR) and the use of NH3 as a reducing agent to selectively react with NO in exhaust gas to produce N2 and H2O [3,4]. At present, NH3-SCR technology is mainly used in two aspects. One is the mobile source exhaust gas treatment system based on diesel engine vehicles, and the other is the traditional exhaust gas treatment system of fixed emission sources such as thermal power plants with coal as the main raw material. V2O5-WO3 (MoO3)/TiO2 has been commercialized for many years as the first generation of NH3-SCR catalyst. Nonetheless, the catalyst continues to have a number of significant issues, such as a narrow catalytic activity window (only applicable to 300 ∼ 400 °C), high SO2 oxidation activity, and its own toxicity [5]. Thus, it is imperative to create novel catalysts with strong NH3-SCR catalytic activity, environmental friendliness, and a wide temperature range. Compared with traditional vanadium metal catalysts, molecular sieve catalysts have many advantages, such as a high acid amount, large specific surface area, good anti-carbon deposition performance, and no secondary pollution. In particular, Cu-modified SSZ-13 molecular sieves have shown great potential for application. Steven J. Schmieg [6] studied the hydrothermal stability of Cu-CHA molecular sieves, and found that the catalytic activity was only slightly reduced after hydrothermal aging at 750 °C for 7 h. C.H He [7] studied the catalytic performance of BEA (β) molecular sieves with different iron loadings. The results showed that the conversion of NOx can be stabilized at more than 80 % between 300 and 500 °C when the silicon-aluminium ratio is 13.5 and the iron loading is 2.5wt%. Feng Gao et al. [8] studied the active sites of iron species on SSZ-13 molecular sieves, and found that isolated Fe3+was the main reaction site in the low temperature region (200–400 °C) during the catalytic SCR reaction, while the dimeric species (2Z-[HO-Fe-O-Fe-OH]2+) of iron played a major role in the higher temperature range (T>400 °C). At the same time, it was found that the larger FexOy particles had higher NH3 oxidation performance. Ja Hun Kwak [9] found that there are two types of copper species in Cu-SSZ-13 molecular sieves: framework copper ([2Z-Cu]2+) and hydroxyl copper ([Z-Cu (OH)] +). The former mainly exists near the double six-membered ring, which has strong interaction with the zeolite framework and good hydrothermal stability. The latter is mainly located near the 8-membered ring and has a weak interaction with the skeleton, which is easy to transform into copper oxide clusters (CuOx)during the hydrothermal process. The Si/Al ratio and molecular sieve topology have a great influence on catalytic activity and hydrothermal stability. The molecular sieve catalyst with a low silica-alumina ratio is more hydrophilic during the hydrothermal process and is vulnerable to the attack of water, resulting in a large area of skeletal aluminium hydrolysis and a decrease in catalytic activity [10]. Raul F. Lobo et al. [11] synthesized Cu-SSZ-13 molecular sieve with silicon and aluminium at about 9 by hydrothermal method, and it can still maintain good hydrothermal stability after thermal and hydro-aging at 750 °C for 16 h. The Qingling Liu team [12] synthesized SSZ-13 molecular sieve with silicon and aluminium at about 13 through coal gangue, which can withstand hydrothermal aging at 800 °C after copper ion exchange. When the silica-alumina ratio is further increased, the hydrothermal stability will decrease sharply. This is because the lower Al makes the content of B acid in the molecular sieve decrease and the increase in the content of hydroxyl copper species aggravates the formation of copper oxide clusters during hydrothermal aging [13]. Consequently, research on the hydrothermal stability of molecular sieves at lower Si/Al ratios is crucial. Compared with the silica-alumina ratio, the difference in the topological structure of the molecular sieve is another factor affecting the catalytic performance of the zeolite. In general, zeolites with high SCR catalytic activity are mostly microporous structures with 8-membered rings and double six-membered rings, and a small number of 10-membered ring pore structures can also exhibit excellent catalytic activity. The hydrothermal stability of LTA zeolites with high Si/Al ratios was investigated by A. Wang et al. [14]. They discovered that Z- [Cu (OH)] + species were more stable and that CuO species may change into hydroxyl copper species during hydrothermal aging. ZSM-5 zeolite with MFI crystal structure shows good catalytic activity after copper ion exchange, but its catalytic performance at high temperatures limits its further development in the field of SCR [15]. In recent years, zeolite with a double topological structure has been a concern. Studies have shown that the bi-crystal zeolite after metal ion exchange exhibits better performance than single crystal catalysis. J.F. Han [16] successfully obtained aluminium-rich OFF-CHA zeolite with double topological structures and found that it can still achieve more than 80 % nitrogen oxide conversion rate in the range of 200–400 °C after hydrothermal aging at 750 °C. Jianxin Cao [19] successfully synthesized bi-crystal molecular sieves with CHA and MFI structures, and showed better performance than MFI single crystal structure in MTO catalytic reaction. The synthesis cycle of the above synthetic bi-crystal or even polycrystalline zeolite is very long, and the synthesis steps are generally cumbersome. It is very important to develop a one-step synthesis of bi-topological zeolite for the field of zeolite catalysis. The T-type zeolite has two crystal structures: OFF and ERI. Compared with the method of synthesizing bi-crystal zeolite mentioned above, the OFF and ERI structures are very similar in crystal structure, and the crystallization process is easy to coexist with the solid phase. Studies have shown that as long as the T-type zeolite contains about 3 % of the ERI structure, it will exhibit excellent gas adsorption and separation performance. However, the synthesis period of T-type zeolite is generally long (7–9 days), which undoubtedly limits the further development of T-type zeolite. Q.Y. Jiang [17] successfully synthesized zeolite T within 5 days by adding a template. N. Jusoh et al. [18] successfully synthesized T-type molecular sieves within 7 days without adding templates by sonic microwave-assisted method. However, due to the low silica-alumina ratio of zeolite T and the long synthesis cycle, there have been few reports on its application in the field of catalysis. It is worth noting that the T-type zeolite has a relatively low silicon-aluminium ratio and has a strong acidity, which provides lots of exchange sites for transition metals, so its performance in the catalytic field is very worth exploring. In this study, zeolite T with a specific surface area of 632m2/g and a Si/Al ratio of 8.4 (measured by XRF Table S1) was synthesized within 24 h by adding a template agent, and a hydrogen-type zeolite T (sample number: F-H-T) was obtained by two ammonium exchanges. A series of Fe-T and Cu-T catalysts were prepared by the ion exchanged method. The crystal structure and morphology were analysed by XRD and SEM. The adsorption performance and pore structure of the catalyst before and after hydrothermal aging were investigated by N2 adsorption-desorption. NH3-TPD was used to examine the changes in the catalyst's acid sites and strength both before and after hydrothermal aging. Using H2-TPR, UV–vis, and XPS, the types and distribution of iron or copper in the catalyst were identified. The NH3-SCR catalytic activity and hydrothermal stability of Cu-T and Fe-T catalysts were systematically studied. In this paper, the feasibility of T-type molecular sieves in the field of industrial tail gas denitrification is demonstrated by a series of characterization methods, which opens up a new direction for non-toxic catalysts for industrial tail gas and provides a new possibility for reducing the synthesis cost of metal-based molecular sieve catalysts. In summary, this is the first time to synthesize T-type molecular sieves by hydrothermal method within 24 h and demonstrates its potential advantages in the field of industrial denitrification. In the future, we can continue to explore its other functions in the field of catalysis. Experimental Preparation of catalyst According to a certain molar ratio, potassium hydroxide (analytically pure, Damao) and sodium hydroxide (analytically pure, Damao) were dissolved in a certain amount of deionized water and stirred until the solution was clarified. Sodium aluminate (99 %, Macklin) and tetramethylammonium hydroxide solution (25 %) were added to the above solution and slowly dropped into the silica sol solution (40 %). After stirring at room temperature for a certain time, it was transferred to a high-temperature and high-pressure hydrothermal reactor lined with polytetrafluoroethylene. Centrifugation and drying were used to obtain the Na/K-T molecular sieve after heating at 130 °C for 24 h. NH4-T molecular sieve was obtained by mixing Na/K-T molecular sieve with NH4Cl solution, stirring for a certain time, and then centrifugal drying. After calcination, the H-T molecular sieve was produced. The XRD and SEM are shown in Figure S1. The NH4-T were ion-exchanged with Cu (NO3)2 or Fe (NO3)3solution with varying concentrations at 60 °C for 2 h to prepare Cu-T or Fe-T zeolite with different Cu2+ or Fe3+ contents. After stirring, washing, centrifugal drying, and calcination at 600 °C for 6 h, six kinds of catalysts with different Cu or Fe loadings were obtained. The element contents of the above six samples were analysed by XRF (Table S1). All samples are labelled as F-Cu (Fe)-T-X/Y (F means freshness; X or Y denotes the content of Cu2+ or Fe3+). Aging samples were obtained by treating F-Cu-T-X in different hydrothermal environments. All aged samples were marked as HY-A/B/CCu/Fe-T-X/Y. A/B/C represents different treatment conditions, and HY means hydrothermal treatment (A:750 °C 16 h 10 %H2O;B:800 °C 6 h 10 %H2O;C:800 °C 6 h 0 %H2O). For instance, the sample of HY-B-Fe-T-4.16wt% or HY-B-Cu-T-4.21wt%. Characterization The Rigaku Ultima IV X-ray diffractometer (XRD) (Rigaku, Japan) was used to characterize the crystal structure of the catalyst. The detection parameters were: scanning voltage 40 kV, scanning current 150 mA, sample scanning speed: 5°/min, and angle range: 5°∼50°. The morphology of the molecular sieve was observed by ZEISS MERLIN Compact high-resolution field emission scanning electron microscopy (SEM). Autosorb-IQ-C-MP automatic physical-chemical adsorption instrument was used to determine the N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms and pore size distribution of the catalyst. NH3-TPD (Ammonia gas Temperature Programmed Desorption) and H2-TPR (Hydrogen Temperature Programmed Reduction) were measured by a Micrometrics AutoChem2920II chemisorption instrument. In the NH3-TPD test, the sample was first pretreated at 500 °C for 30 min in an Ar environment, followed by adsorption at 20 % NH3/Ar for 60 min at atmospheric pressure (adsorption temperature of 100 °C) and then purged by Ar for 60 min under the same conditions. In the H2-TPR test, the sample was also pretreated at 500 °C for 30 min in Ar environment, cooled to 100 °C, purged in Ar environment for 30 min, then heated to a specific temperature at a heating rate of 10 °C/min in a 10 %H2/Ar (30 ml/min) mixed gas environment.27Al MAS NMR (Magic Angle Spinning) was collected on the AVANCE-NEO-600 M (Bruker, Germany) nuclear magnetic resonance spectrometer. XPS was performed on a NEXSA (Thermos Fisher, USA) X-ray photoelectron spectrometer to determine the elemental composition of the catalyst surface. UV–vis was tested using a UV-2600 (Shimadzu, Japan) UV–vis spectrophotometer at 200–800 nm. A S8 TIGER (Bruker, Germany) X-ray fluorescence spectrometer (XRF) was used to determine the content of each substance in the sample. NH3-SCR activity test The NH3-SCR performance of the catalyst was carried out on the catalyst evaluation device. The concentration of NO, NO2, N2O, CO2, NH3, and other gases was detected simultaneously by the MKS Multi Gas 6030 Fourier transform infrared spectrometer. The total flow rate was held at 1000 ml/min, with a gas composition of 500ppmNO,500ppmNH3,5 %O2,5 %CO2, 5 %H2O and N2 as balance gas. 0.3 g catalyst with 20–30 mesh was used for the test, with gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) of∼100000h−. The test temperature is 100 °C-600 °C, and the heating rate is 5 °C/min. The activity of the catalyst is expressed by the conversion of NO and the selectivity of N2, and the specific formula is shown in Formula (1–1). The N2 selectivity calculation formula is shown in (1–2). X N O ( % ) = [ N O ] i n − [ N O ] o u t [ N O ] i n × 100 % N 2 s e l e c t i c i t y ( % ) = [ N O ] i n + [ N H 3 ] i n − [ N O 2 ] o u t − [ N O ] o u t − [ N H 3 ] o u t − 2 N 2 O o u t [ N O ] i n + [ N H 3 ] i n − [ N O ] o u t − [ N H 3 ] o u t × 100 % ( 1 − 2 ) Results NH3-SCR performance The NO conversion of Fe-T and Cu-T catalysts in the standard NH3-SCR reaction is shown in Figs. 1 and 2 (100–600 °C, GHSV= 100000h−). As shown in Figs. 1a and 2a, fresh Fe-T and Cu-T catalysts showed excellent NO catalytic activity. The NO conversion of all Fe-T samples can reach more than 80 % at about 300 °C (Fig. 1a), and the F-Fe-T-6.20wt% can be maintained at more than 80 % between 290 and 600 °C. At the same time, the NO conversion rate of the Cu-T series catalyst (Fig. 2a) can reach 50 % around 150 °C. F-Cu-T-5.74wt% has better low-temperature activity (the conversion rate reaches 50 % at 144 °C,80 % at 166 °C), while F-Cu-T-3.33wt% has better high-temperature activity (the NO conversion rate is still not less than 93 % in the range of 500–600 °C). In addition, the samples modified by the two metal ions showed very high N2 selectivity (Fig.S2). The F-Fe-T catalyst can maintain more than 99 % selectivity at 100–600 °C, and the N2O production is less than 1 ppm (Fig. S2a), while the F-Cu-T catalyst can also maintain more than 98 % N2 selectivity, and the N2O production is less than 15 ppm (Fig. S2b). Although the copper-modified catalyst has better low-temperature catalytic activity, the nitrogen selectivity of the iron-modified T-type molecular sieve is slightly higher. It should be noted that the NO conversion rate of the iron-modified sample decreased between 550 and 600 °C, which may be due to the oxidation of NH3 by some oligomeric iron oxide species in the catalyst to produce amount of NO [8]. Figs. 1b and 2b are the conversion rates of NO with temperature change after hydrothermal aging treatment of two types of catalysts under B condition. It can be clearly seen that the hydrothermal stability of Fe-T series catalysts is higher than that of Cu-T catalysts. After hydrothermal aging, the catalytic activity of HY-B-Fe-T series catalysts decreased. The conversion rate of NO decreased by about 22.39 % at 300 °C. The iron-based zeolite after aging treatment can reach 80 % conversion rate at about 300 °C. In sharp contrast, the NH3-SCR catalytic performance of Cu-T catalyst was seriously degraded after hydrothermal aging under B condition, and the NO conversion rate did not exceed 40 % in the range of 100–600 °C. This obvious difference is unexpected. In order to explore the difference of hydrothermal stability of T-type zeolite modified by Cu2+ and Fe3+, the Cu-T catalyst was treated under hydrothermal aging A (750 °C, 16 h, 10 % H2O) and thermal aging C (800 °C, 6 h, 0 % H2O), respectively. The catalytic results are shown in Figure S3. Under the condition of hydrothermal aging A, HY-A-Cu-T-4.21wt% showed the best catalytic activity, while the catalytic performance of HY-A-Cu-T-3.33wt% and HY-A-Cu-T-5.74wt% decreased significantly. However, it can be seen that not all the samples showed deactivation of the catalyst after reducing the aging conditions, indicating that the temperature had a great influence on the Cu-T catalyst. Under the condition of thermal aging C, the catalyst also showed deactivation (Fig.S3b), indicating that the effect of temperature on the catalyst was more significant. It is worth noting that although there have been many reports on the application of T-type molecular sieves in the field of gas separation [19–21], few people have explored the catalytic performance of T-type molecular sieves in the field of NH3-SCR after metal ion modification. After some of the above activity tests, it was found that the T-zeolite has a greater catalytic advantage. In addition, the hydrothermal stability of the catalyst after iron ion exchange is better than that of copper-exchanged. Structural analysis The crystal structures of H-T and Cu (Fe)-T catalysts of fresh and hydrothermal aging were studied by XRD, SEM, N2 adsorption-desorption, and 27Al MAS NMR, respectively. As shown in Fig 3 , XRD crystal diffraction data show that all fresh samples have high crystallinity, indicating that there is no significant difference in the crystallinity of T-type molecular sieves under different metal contents (Fig. 3a). In contrast, the XRD patterns obtained under B aging conditions show a very large difference (Fig. 3b). No characteristic peaks of zeolite T (2θ=6.6–6.7°) were observed in all Cu-T series samples, which means that the crystal structure of the HY-B-Cu-T catalyst has been completely destroyed. It is worth noting that although the XRD diffraction peak intensity of the Fe3+ modified T-type molecular sieve after aging under B conditions has a significant decrease, the characteristic peak of the T-type zeolite has not completely disappeared, which means that the crystal structure of the HY-B-Fe-T series samples is still long-range ordered. Interestingly, with the increase in iron content, the XRD diffraction peak intensity of HY-B-Fe-T catalyst gradually increased (Fig. 3b). This indicates that the stability of T zeolite framework is improved with an increase in iron content. Similarly, the XRD patterns of the Cu-T series samples treated under hydrothermal aging A conditions showed that HY-A-Cu-3.33wt% and HY-A-Cu-4.21wt% retained most of the crystal structure, while the HY-A-Cu-5.74wt% sample decreased significantly, but the catalyst still showed a certain characteristic peak of the T-type molecular sieve (Figure S4). Last but not least, the XRD results of Cu-T series samples after thermal aging under the C condition are almost the same as those under condition B, that is, there is no diffraction peak information about the crystal structure of T zeolite in the range of 2θ = 5–50° The XRD results of Cu-T series samples treated under hydrothermal aging A and thermal aging C conditions correspond to their NH3-SCR catalytic activity, which again shows that temperature has a great influence on the stability of Cu-T series catalysts. The adsorption-desorption curve shows that (Fig. 4 ) the N2 adsorption content of HY-B-Fe-T series samples increases sharply within a relatively low relative pressure (P/P0<0.01), which indicates that the sample still retains part of the microporous structure. The percentage of microporous structure (0.3–2 nm) grew together with the iron content (Fig. 5 a), indicating that the catalyst's pore structure became more stable as the iron level rose. This rise was consistent with the XRD data. Moreover, the change in specific surface area of Fe-T catalyst after hydrothermal aging under B conditions also proved this point (Table 1 [5–7]), that is, the specific surface area of the sample increased gradually with the increase in iron loading. Compared with the fresh samples, the specific surface area of HY-B-Fe-T-4.16wt% lost 43.59 % and HY-B-Fe-T-8.09wt% only lost 28.79 %, which suggests that the hydrothermal stability of T-type zeolite was indeed increased by iron ions (see table S2 [5–7] for fresh sample data).On the other hand, the copper-based catalyst lost about 99 % of the specific surface area after aging under B hydrothermal conditions (Table 1 [2–4]), and all the HY-B-Cu-T catalysts almost lost the N2 adsorption capacity. The adsorption isotherm showed a typical type III isotherm (Fig. 4b), and its microporous structure was basically completely lost. (Fig. 5b). The pore volume distribution in Fig. 5b shows that there are still 4 %−6 % micropores in the HY-B-Cu-T catalyst, but the N2 adsorption capacity of Fig. 4b does not increase significantly in the low-pressure range (P/P0<0.01), which may be due to the small content of micropores. In summary, the hydrothermal stability of the Fe-T catalyst is better than that of the Cu-T series catalyst. In order to further explore the effect of Cu2+ and Fe3+ on the pore structure of T zeolite, F-H-T zeolite was treated under B and C conditions, respectively. The adsorption and desorption isotherms are shown in Fig.S5. Surprisingly, the adsorption capacity of the HY-B-H-T sample only decreased slightly. The specific areas of the F- H-T zeolite before and after hydrothermal aging were 632 m2/g (fresh), and 478 m2/g (B conditions), 513 m2/g (C conditions), and most of the micropores were also retained (lower right of Fig.S5). Compared with fresh samples, the specific surface area of HY-B-T samples lost 24.36%, HY-B-Fe-T-8.09wt% lost 28.79 %, and HY-B-Cu-T-5.74wt% lost 99.15 %. This indicates that the effect of iron species on T-type molecular sieves is much smaller than that of copper species. In addition, after comparing the isothermal adsorption desorption curve (Figure S6a) and pore volume distribution (Figure S6b) of fresh and aged (B Hydrothermal aging conditions) Cu-SSZ-13 zeolites, it was found that the adsorption capacity and pore size distribution did not change significantly. The specific surface area of the F-Cu-SSZ-13–5.94wt% catalyst was 708 m2/g, and the HY-B-Cu-SSZ-13–5.94wt% was 658 m2/g. The specific surface area of the aged sample was lost 7 % (Table S4). This indicates that the decrease of hydrothermal stability of T-type zeolite after copper ion exchange is obviously related to the crystal structure of zeolite (CHA structure is mainly eight-membered ring and double six-membered ring, while there are more 12-membered rings in OFF-ERI structure). The specific surface area and isothermal adsorption and desorption curves of Cu-T catalyst after treatment under A and C conditions are shown in Table S3 and Fig.S7. It can be seen that HY-A-Cu-T-3.33wt% and HY-A-Cu-T-4.21wt% both retain a considerable part of the microporous structure. The adsorption and desorption curve of HY-A-Cu-T-5.74wt% shows that the sample has lost most of its adsorption capacity and the pore structure of the sample has become larger, which is completely consistent with the results presented by XRD. The isothermal adsorption desorption curves of HY-C-Cu-T series samples also show a typical type III isotherm (Fig.S7b), which is related to the destruction of the microporous structure of the crystal structure collapses. This result is also consistent with the XRD results discussed above. The SEM images of Fe-T-4.16wt% and Cu-T-4.21wt% catalysts before and after hydrothermal aging are shown in Fig 6 . It can be seen that the crystal morphology of the two series of catalysts before and after hydrothermal aging did not change significantly (Fig. 6a-d). By carefully comparing the two pictures of 6e and f, it is found that the roughness of the surface of F-Fe-T-4.16wt% and HY-B-Fe-T-4.16wt% samples have a more obvious change. This may be due to the fact that some iron oxide clusters attached to the surface of the T-type molecular sieve during the preparation of the F-Fe-T-4.16wt% sample (Fig. e), resulting in a rough crystal appearance, while the surface of the HY-B-Fe-T-4.16wt% sample (Fig. 6f) is smoother due to the re-dispersion of iron oxide particles on the outer surface during hydrothermal aging. Fig. 6g, h is the crystal morphology picture of Cu-T-4.21wt% catalyst before and after hydrothermal aging treatment under B hydrothermal aging conditions. It can be seen that some obvious larger species appeared on the surface of the sample in Fig. 6h, which is likely to be the copper oxide clusters produced by the Cu-T series catalysts after hydrothermal aging. Fig. 7 shows the 27Al MAS NMR spectra of Fe-T-4.16wt% and Cu-T-4.21wt% before and after hydrothermal treatment. The four samples all have resonance peaks near 57 ppm, 48 ppm, and 0 ppm. According to previous studies, the peak at 57 ppm belongs to the four-coordinated framework Al, and the peaks near 48 ppm and 0 ppm belong to the five-coordinated and six-coordinated non-framework Al [22–24]. In addition, two rotational sideband peaks symmetrical to the main peak (57 ppm) were generated near 135 ppm and −20 ppm of the two spectra. As shown in Figs.7a, b, the F-Fe-T-4.16wt% and F-Cu-T-4.21wt% samples produced a strong skeleton Al absorption peak at 57 ppm, which means that there are a large number of four-coordinated skeleton Al (Al [OSi]4). However, the peak of the HY-B-Cu-T-4.21wt% sample at 57 ppm almost disappeared, indicating that the Cu-T-4.21wt% had a serious dealumination under the B aging condition, which was consistent with the XRD results. The HY-B-Fe-T-4.16wt% catalyst still retained about 40 % of the framework Al, indicating that part of the framework Al of the HY-B-Fe-T-4.16wt% catalyst was retained during hydrothermal aging. The 27Al MAS NMR resonance spectra of F-Fe-T-4.16wt% (Fig. 7a) and F-Cu-T-4.21wt% (Fig. 7b) were carefully compared. It can be found that the peak of F-Fe-T-4.16wt% catalyst at 57 ppm was slightly weaker than that of F-Cu-T-4.21wt%. In addition, F-Fe-T-4.16wt% showed an obvious non-framework 6-coordinated Al resonance absorption peak at −2.5 ppm, while F-Cu-T-4.21wt% did not. This indicates that the loading of Fe3+ and Cu2+ has a certain effect on the framework Al of T-type molecular sieves. It may be that some Fe3+ is combined with the framework Al to form Fe-O-Al species, which promotes the transformation of some framework Al into non-framework Al. This part of Al may be protected by Fe3+during hydrothermal aging, making it difficult to detach from the skeleton or hydrolyse. In fact, the results of H2-TPR and UV–vis showed that there were small FeOx clusters in the F-Fe-T-6wt% catalyst samples. These small clusters gradually dispersed into isolated [Z-Fe3+OH)2] + during hydrothermal aging. This will be discussed in detail in the following chapters. In summary, the following conclusions can be drawn: First of all, aluminium-rich T-type molecular sieves exhibit excellent NO catalytic activity after modification with copper or iron ions. Secondly, the effect of copper species on the framework of T-type zeolite is much greater than that of iron species. Acid sites Fig 8 . shows the fresh and aged NH3-TPD curves of Fe-T-4.16wt% (a) and Cu-T-4.21wt% (b). The data were fitted by a Gaussian function to calculate the peak area ratio and the corresponding NH3 adsorption capacity (Table 2 ). According to the relevant literature, the peak below 200 °C is the weak physical adsorption of NH3 by the sample. The desorption peak at 200–300 °C is due to the adsorption of NH3 by L acid produced by metal exchange sites and zeolite framework (Crystal defects or some non-skeleton Al) [25]. The desorption peaks near high temperature (400–500 °C) are mainly due to the strong B acid adsorption of NH3, NH3 is mainly combined with zeolite framework (Si-(OH)-Si) in proton form (NH4）+ [26,27]. As shown in Fig. 8c, d, HY-B-Cu-T-4.21wt% almost lost its adsorption capacity for NH3 while HY-B-Fe-T-4.16wt% still retained some acidic sites. HY-B-Cu-T-4.21 wt% molecular sieve almost lost the ability to adsorb NH3, indicating that the Si- (OH) -Al species and various Cu species in the catalyst were seriously affected. On the other hand, the disappearance of strong B acid sites in HY-B-Cu-T-4.21wt% is consistent with the results of 27Al MAS NMR. The decrease in framework Al content will inevitably lead to a decrease in Si- (OH) -Al species content. This can also further illustrate that the Al in the HY-B-Cu-T-4.21wt% catalyst did not return to the zeolite framework after the hydrothermal aging, otherwise, the aged catalyst should still retain a considerable part of the acid sites. As shown in Fig. 8a, c, the NH3-TPD curve of Fe-T-4.16wt% before and after hydrothermal aging shows that the adsorption capacity of strong B acid (peak IV) of F-Fe-T-4.16wt% is 0.58 mmol/g, accounting for 32.73 %. The adsorption capacity of L acid (peak III) is 0.52 mmol/g, accounting for 29.54 %. The adsorption capacity of strong B acid HY-B-Fe-T-4.16wt% is 0.13 mmol/g, accounting for 25.84 %, and the adsorption capacity of L acid is 0.16 mmol/g, accounting for 32 % (Table 2). The decrease of the overall acid content of HY-B-Fe-T-4.16 wt% is due to the transformation of some isolated iron species into FeXOy clusters after hydrothermal aging. This also indicates that the NH3-SCR performance of HY-B-Fe-T series catalysts decreases. On the other hand, the increase of L acid content from 29.54 % to 32 % in HY-B-Fe-T-4.16wt% sample may be related to Fe3+ produced during hydrothermal aging, which will be further discussed in the following chapters. Metal species The transition metal (Cu2+/Fe3+) can absorb ultraviolet and visible light at a specific wavelength, so that the metal species in the zeolite framework can be distinguished [28]. As shown in Fig. 9 a, the UV–Vis spectra of iron species can be roughly divided into three regions: the region between 200 and 300 nm is attributed to the isolated Fe3+,300–400 nm can be attributed to the iron oligomer (including 2Z-[HO-Fe-O-Fe-OH]2+) inside the channel, and 400–600 nm is due to the larger iron oxide aggregates (FexOy) [29–31]. As shown in Fig. 9b, the band between 200 and 235 nm is attributed to the electronic transition of Cu+ (3d10→3d94S1) [32],235–300 nm can be attributed to the CuOx species [33]. 300–600 nm is related to the d-d transition between linear copper oxide ([Cu-O-Cu]2+),600–800 nm is caused by the d-d transition of Cu2+ [34–36]. As shown in Fig. 9a, compared with the fresh sample, the absorption peak area of HY-B-Fe-T-4.16wt% in the range of 400–600 nm decreased while the absorption intensity in the range of 200–400 nm increased significantly. At the same time, there was an obvious absorption peak near 550 nm. Compared with the UV–vis spectrum of Fe2O3 (Fig.S8a), it can be seen that the absorption peak should belong to the larger iron oxide species [37]. By carefully observing the UV–vis absorption spectrum between 600 and 700 nm, it can be found that the absorption peak area of F-Fe-4.16wt% in this range is significantly larger than that of HY-B-Fe-T-4.16wt%. This could be because, when the Fe-T sample is being prepared, some loosely agglomerated FeOx species are adhered to the T-type molecular sieve's surface. This part of the iron species is re-dispersed into an isolated Fe3+ species during the hydrothermal aging process and enters the internal channel of the molecular sieve, which is particularly evident in the subsequent XPS test. It is worth noting that the increase in isolated Fe3+ content in HY-B-Fe-T-4.16wt% did not increase its NH3-SCR low-temperature catalytic activity, which may be due to the large particle iron oxide clusters, which have high NH3 oxidation activity and thus inhibit the conversion of NO. As shown in Fig. 8b, compared with the fresh sample, the band of HY-B-Cu-T-4.21wt% between 600 and 800 nm did not change significantly, indicating that the content of Cu2+ did not change significantly before and after aging, but only the form of Cu2+ changed. The change of spectrum between 200 and 400 nm also proved this point. Compared with Fig.S7b, it can be realized that the UV absorption peak generated near 250 nm belongs to the CuOx species. The absorption peak of the aged sample near 210 nm gradually becomes larger. This is because the copper species migrates to form more copper-oxygen complexes during the aging process, which reduces the valence of the copper species and produces a large amount of Cu+(3d10→3d94S1) charge transition [38]. The increase of absorption peak intensity between 235 and 300 nm band can explain the increase of CuOx species in HY-B-Cu-T-4.21wt% sample [39]. Combined with XRD results, it can be clearly felt that the larger particles of copper-oxygen complexes have a greater destructive effect on the structure of zeolites during hydrothermal aging, while the iron species, although also generating some iron oxide species during hydrothermal aging, do not seem to destroy the framework of zeolites. The changes of metal species in Fe-T and Cu-T catalysts before and after hydrothermal treatment were further explored by H2-TPR. The H2-TPR spectra of fresh and aged Fe-T-4.16wt% catalysts are shown in Fig. 10 ac. According to previous studies, isolated Fe3+is reduced to Fe2+ near 300 °C, and Fe3O4 is reduced to FeO between 400 and 450 °C (Including the dimeric iron species partially located at the exchange site) . The peak at 500–600 °C is caused by the reduction of FeOx (low polymer iron oxide) to Fe3O4, and the reduction peak above 600 °C is caused by the reduction of high polymer FeXOy. The reduction temperature of Fe2+ is generally 900–1000 °C, which is not shown here [40–42]. Fig. 10b, d show the H2-TPR spectra of Cu-T series before and after hydrothermal treatment. The reduction peak at 282 °C is Z-[Cu2+(OH)] + species with strong activity. The interaction between 2Z-Cu2+ and skeleton is strong, so the reduction temperature is generally near 400 °C. The reduction peak near 350 °C is CuOx species, and the reduction peak near 500 °C is CuAlOx, the reduction peaks above 500 °C are generally attributed to Cu +species [36,43–45]. As shown in Fig. 10a, c, the samples before and after hydrothermal treatment produced two peaks in the range of 300–500 °C, indicating that the reduction of Fe3+→Fe2+ is a very important process in the SCR reaction. The three reduction peaks produced by HY-Fe-T-4.16wt% shifted to high temperatures compared with the fresh sample, indicating that the oxidation ability of iron species decreased after hydrothermal aging. The peak area of Fe3O4 species in HY-B-Fe-T-4.16wt% catalyst decreased from 70.67 % to 50.82 %, and the area of iron oxide clusters increased from fresh 6.36 % to 34.18 % (Table 3 ). This indicates that some Fe3O4 or dimeric iron species agglomerated during the hydrothermal aging process, which is consistent with the results presented by UV–vis. The FeOx species in the HY-B-Fe-T-4.16wt% sample disappeared, which may be due to the formation of oligomeric iron oxides (FeOx) formed during the preparation of fresh samples and attached to the surface of the molecular sieve. During the hydrothermal aging process, this part of the iron oxide may be re-dispersed, part of the formation of new isolated Fe3+, and more is the formation of larger particles of iron oxide. This is also consistent with the results presented by UV–vis. As shown in Fig. 10b, the copper in the F-Cu-T-4.21wt% sample mainly exists in the form of Z-[Cu2+(OH)] + and 2Z-Cu2+.In addition, some CuOx clusters were also formed in the fresh sample. It can be seen that a large number of CuAlOx species were formed in the HY-B-Cu-T-4.21wt% sample after treatment under B hydrothermal aging conditions (Fig. 10d). This species has been proven not to have SCR catalytic activity, and the formation of a large amount of CuAlOx is also related to the hydrolysis of the T-type zeolite framework Al. The hydrolysis of a large amount of framework Al destroyed the framework structure of the T-type zeolite, which was also confirmed by the results of 27Al MAS NMR and XRD. It is worth noting that the content of Cu+ (900–1000 °C) in the F-Cu-T-4.21wt% sample is only 22.19 %, which indicates that some of the stable framework Cu+ located inside the zeolite is not reduced, which may require higher temperature [46]. At the same time, after comparing the H2-TPR pattern of CuO (Fig.S9a), it is found that it may also be related to the direct reduction of CuOx species in the sample (Cu2+→ Cu0). In addition, the reduction temperature of Cu+in the HY-B-Cu-T-4.21wt% sample moved to about 700 °C, indicating that the dealumination of zeolite and the destruction of crystal structure weakened the stability of Cu+ in the framework, making Cu+ easier to be reduced [47]. Compared with the H2-TPR of Cu2O (Figure S9b), it was found that the simpler coordination environment made Cu+ easier to be reduced. The content of Cu+ in HY-B-Cu-T-4.21wt% catalyst is only 10.4 %, which may also be related to the direct reduction of a large number of CuOx and CuAlOx species. Moreover, the XRD results (Fig. 3b) show that the HY-B-Fe-T-4.16wt% sample retains most of the crystal structure, so the phenomenon that the Fe2+ reduction peak moves to low temperature is not observed in its H2-TPR spectrum (Fig. 10c), which also indicates that the strong interaction between the skeleton structure and Cu+ (Fe2+) is one of the reasons why it is difficult to be reduced. In order to better observe the changes of metal species on the surface of fresh and aged catalysts, the catalysts were analysed by XPS, and the results are shown in Fig. 11 . It can be seen that the peaks of Fe2P3/2 and Fe2P1/2 were observed in the range of 710–730ev in both F-Fe-T-4.16wt% and HY-B-Fe-T-4.16wt%. The peak at 710ev was Fe2+ (FeO) species, and the peak at 712ev was attributed to Fe3+ (Fe2O3) [25,48–50]. The peaks of Cu2P1/2 and Cu2P3/2 were also observed at 925–965ev for F-Cu-T-4.21wt% and HY-B-Cu-T-4.21wt%. The peak at 933.39ev is Cu+, the peak at 934.18ev is Cu2+ [51,52]. As shown in Table 4 , compared with F-Fe-T-4.16wt%, the proportion of Fe3+ on the surface of the HY-B-Fe-T-4.16wt% catalyst decreased from 88.5 % to 77.62 %, while the proportion of Fe2+ increased from 11.5 % to 22.38 %. It shows that some Fe3+ is converted into Fe2+ during hydrothermal aging. The percentage of iron atoms on the surface of HY-B-Fe-T-4.16wt% sample decreased from 15.76 at% of the fresh sample to 7.54 at% (Table 4). At the same time, the peak intensity of HY-B-Fe-T-4.16wt% sample was smaller than that of F-Fe-T-4.16wt% (Fig.S10a), which indicated that the overall content of iron species on the surface of the catalyst decreased after aging. This is because there are some oligomeric FeOx species on the outer surface of the fresh sample. On the contrary, the peak intensity of HY-B-Cu-T-4.21wt% is higher than that of F-Cu-T-4.21wt% (Fig.S10b). The percentage of copper atoms on the surface of HY-B-Cu-T-4.21wt% samples increased from 0.81 at% of fresh samples to 1.55 at% (Table 4). It is indicated that most of the Cu species in the Cu-T-4.21wt% catalyst migrated from the inside of the molecular sieve to the outside after hydrothermal aging under B conditions. At the same time, the proportion of Cu+ on the surface of HY-B-Cu-T-4.21wt% increased from 23.66 % to 49.36 % (Table 4), indicating that the content of CuOx clusters on the surface of the catalyst sample increased, and the copper oxide became more complex, which was consistent with the results of H2-TPR and UV–vis. It is well known that the hydrolysis of the framework Al leads to a decrease in the acidity of the catalyst. Discussion Catalytic activity Both Fe-T and Cu-T catalysts exhibited excellent NH3-SCR catalytic performance. The NO conversion of Fe-T series catalysts reached more than 80% between 290 °C and 600 °C, while the NO conversion of Cu-T series catalysts reached more than 80 % between 160 °C and 600 °C. This is consistent with the performance of Cu-SSZ-13–5.94wt%, and Fe-BEA −7.87wt% catalysts (Figure S11 a c) . However, the catalytic activity of HY-B-Cu-T-5.74wt% after B hydrothermal aging treatment was much lower than that of HY-B-Cu-SSZ-13–5.94wt% (Figure S11b). This may be related to the crystal structure of the molecular sieve. The OFF-structure accounts for up to 90 % of the T-type zeolite, and the OFF structure has a large number of 12-membered ring structures (pore diameter of 5.8–6.7 Å). The three-dimensional channel diagram of the OFF structure is shown in Fig. 12 a. It can be clearly seen that the main channel of the OFF includes the channel formed by the 8-membered ring on the side (I→III) and the channel formed by the 12-membered ring in the Z-axis direction (IV). Although the 12-membered ring channel increases the gas flux in the NH3-SCR reaction, it also increases the migration of copper species in hydrothermal aging and reduces the hydrothermal stability of the framework Al. The main structure of the SSZ-13 molecular sieve is a cage structure dominated by 8-membered rings. The pore radius is about 3.8 Å, and the main pore is mainly composed of 8-membered rings (Fig. 12b). This undoubtedly reduces the migration of Cu species and also makes the crystal structure of Cu-SSZ-13 preserved in hydrothermal aging under B conditions. In addition, as shown in Fig.S11c, d, the NH3-SCR catalytic activity of Fe-T-8.09wt% is comparable to that of Fe-BEA-7.87 wt% after fresh and aging treatments, which once again confirms that T-type molecular sieves have potential advantages in the field of industrial denitrification. Hydrothermal stability It is well known that the hydrothermal stability of zeolite catalysts is related to the Si/Al ratio (Si/Al) and the framework structure. Zeolites with a lower Si/Al ratio tend to form 2Z-Cu2+ more easily in the process of copper ion modification, which can increase the hydrothermal stability of zeolites to a certain extent. Professor He Hong [53] has explored the NH3-SCR catalytic performance and hydrothermal stability of Cu-SSZ-13 (CHA) and Cu-SSZ-39 (AEI) crystal structures in detail. Finally, they found that the AEI structure makes it difficult for the Al species to break away from the skeleton during the hydrothermal aging process due to its more tortuous pore structure, so that a considerable part of the Al species can return to the skeleton after the hydrothermal aging. However, it is obvious that the hydrothermal stability of the same structure modified by different metal ions is also significantly affected. The crystal structure of Cu-T series catalysts after hydrothermal aging under B conditions showed long-range disorder, and the diffraction peak intensity of XRD crystal almost disappeared, while the XRD diffraction peak intensity of Fe-T series catalysts remained at least 50 %. 27Al MAS NMR results (Fig. 7) showed that the HY-B-Fe-T-4.16 wt% sample had more skeleton Al than the HY-B-Cu-T-4.21 wt% sample. It seems that the Fe species have less influence on the skeleton Al, so that the hydrothermal stability of the Fe-T series catalyst is higher than that of the Cu-T series catalyst. Moreover, the framework Al of HY-B-Cu-T-4.21wt% is almost depleted, resulting in the loss of most of the acidity. The HY-B-Fe-T-4.16wt% sample retains about 40 % of the framework Al, which allows the sample to keep some acidic sites after aging. The above conclusions are consistent with the results shown by NH3-TPD (Fig. 8). The physical adsorption desorption curve further proves that the Fe species are more conducive to the stability of the skeleton. The molecular sieve (H-T type sample) before metal ion modification lost 24.36 % of the specific surface area after hydrothermal aging under B condition, 28.79 % after iron ion modification, and 99.15 % after copper ion modification. In summary, the introduction of copper species seriously reduces the hydrothermal stability of T-type molecular sieves, while iron species have little effect on the molecular sieve skeleton. Fig. 13 is a schematic diagram of the migration and transformation of some iron species in the Fe-T catalyst during the hydrothermal aging process. It may be that this part of the FeOx clusters with low degree of agglomeration transformed into isolated Fe3+ during the hydrothermal aging process and migrated to the adjacent skeleton Al site. This has a protective effect on the skeleton Al to a certain extent. In contrast, as shown in Fig. 14 , most of the copper species in the fresh Cu-T catalyst exist in the form of 2Z-Cu2+ and Z- [Cu (OH)] +. Large number of CuOx clusters and CuAlOx species are formed during the hydrothermal aging process, resulting in the fracture of the skeleton and a serious decrease in catalytic activity. Conclusion In this experiment, highly crystalline T-type molecular sieves were rapidly synthesized within 24 h by using tetramethylammonium hydroxide as an organic template additive, and the NH3-SCR catalytic activity and hydrothermal stability of Fe-T and Cu-T series catalysts were studied. Both types of catalysts exhibit excellent NH3-SCR catalytic activity. The fresh Cu-T series catalysts have excellent low-temperature activity, while the fresh Fe-T catalysts have excellent high-temperature activity. The T-type molecular sieve after Fe ion modification can maintain a crystal structure of about 50 % −60 % after treatment at 800 °C, 10% H2O 6 h, and more than 80% catalytic activity between 350 and 600 °C. This is due to the formation of some smaller FeOx species with lower degree of agglomeration during the preparation of Fe-T series catalysts. This species is re-dispersed into isolated Fe3+ during hydrothermal aging, thus protecting part of the skeleton Al. At the same time, the content of dimeric iron decreased after hydrothermal aging, and the content of larger FexOy species increased significantly, which led to the decrease of catalytic activity of Fe-T catalysts after hydrothermal aging. The crystal structure of Cu-T series catalysts was completely destroyed after hydrothermal aging under the same conditions, and the catalytic activity decreased seriously. This may be related to the large number of 12-membered ring structures in T-type molecular sieves, and the 12-membered ring structure is almost unbending, so a large number of Z- [Cu2+ (OH)] + species migrate during hydrothermal aging, forming larger CuOx and CuAlOx clusters, which destroy the structural stability of the framework Al. As a result, the hydrothermal stability of Cu-T series catalysts is not as good as that of Fe-T series catalysts. coredata.dc:description: In this experiment, a highly crystalline T-type zeolite was rapidly synthesized by hydrothermal method within 24 h and its NH3-SCR catalytic performance after Cu2+or Fe3+modification was studied. The experimental results show that T-type molecular sieve is workable in industrial tail gas denitrification. The F-Fe-T series samples can maintain more than 80 % of the nitrogen oxide conversion rate in the range of 280–600 °C and the F-Cu-T catalyst could achieve more than 80 % at about 170 °C. At the same time, it was found that the zeolites modified by two metal ions had obvious differences in hydrothermal stability. The results suggested that the Fe-T catalyst can maintain excellent crystal structure and NH3-SCR catalytic activity even after hydrothermal aging at 800 °C for 6 h, but the skeleton structure of the Cu-T catalyst is completely destroyed. The main reason may be that a small amount of FeOx species with a low degree of agglomeration formed in the fresh Fe-T series catalysts, which interacted with the framework Al to form Fe-O-Al species and FeOx species were re-dispersed into isolated Fe3+species during hydrothermal aging, thus avoiding a large amount of hydrolysis of the framework Al. The framework Al of Cu-T series catalysts are hydrolysed during hydrothermal aging, which leads to the deactivation of the catalyst. In summary, T-type zeolites exhibit excellent catalytic activity after copper or iron ion exchange, but the Fe-T series catalysts have better hydrothermal stability.
coredata.dc:title: Investigation of the differences in the DeNO(x) performance and hydrothermal stability of T zeolite catalysts modified with copper & iron
